questions.question: What is the primary advantage of using a general inter-arrival time distribution (GI) over a Poisson distribution in the GI/M/1 model?

answers.a: GI allows for more accurate representation of real-world arrival patterns.
answers.c: GI guarantees a higher system stability.
answers.d: Poisson distribution leads to shorter waiting times.

explanations.a: Correct. Using a general inter-arrival time distribution allows for more accurate representation of real-world arrival patterns in the GI/M/1 model.
explanations.b: Incorrect. While Poisson distribution is computationally simpler, it may not accurately capture the variability in arrival times.
explanations.c: Incorrect. System stability is not guaranteed solely by using a general inter-arrival time distribution.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Poisson distribution does not necessarily lead to shorter waiting times compared to a general inter-arrival time distribution.

questions.question: In the GI/M/1 model, what effect does increasing the service rate have on the average waiting time?

answers.d: It depends on the arrival rate.

explanations.a: Correct. Increasing the service rate typically decreases the average waiting time in the GI/M/1 model.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Increasing the service rate generally leads to shorter waiting times.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Increasing the service rate does not typically increase the average waiting time.
explanations.d: Incorrect. The effect of increasing the service rate on the average waiting time is not dependent on the arrival rate in the GI/M/1 model.

questions.question: What does the term 'M' represent in the GI/M/1 queueing system notation?

explanations.a: Incorrect. 'M' does not represent the mean service rate in the GI/M/1 notation.
explanations.b: Incorrect. 'M' does not represent the Markovian arrival process in the GI/M/1 notation.
explanations.c: Incorrect. 'M' does not represent the maximum queue length in the GI/M/1 notation.
explanations.d: Correct. 'M' represents memoryless service time distribution in the GI/M/1 queueing system notation.

questions.question: How does the concept of 'first-come, first-served' (FCFS) scheduling apply in the GI/M/1 queueing system?

answers.a: Customers are served based on their arrival times without any priority.
answers.b: Customers with higher priority are served first.
answers.c: Customers with shorter service requirements are served first.
answers.d: Service is allocated randomly to customers.

explanations.a: Correct. 'First-come, first-served' (FCFS) scheduling means customers are served based on their arrival times without any priority in the GI/M/1 queueing system.
explanations.b: Incorrect. FCFS scheduling does not prioritize customers based on their priority levels.
explanations.c: Incorrect. FCFS scheduling does not prioritize customers based on their service requirements.
explanations.d: Incorrect. FCFS scheduling does not allocate service randomly to customers.
